title: Tuesday, 23rd May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Tuesday, then. And a picture.

BE11:04am

That's the Unknown Pleasures mosaic outside Afflecks Palace, in Manchester's Northern Quarter.

BE11:04am

(Pic credit: Duncan Hull on Flickr: https://www.flickr.com/photos/dullhunk/ )

11:04 am
BE11:04am

And I'm afraid it comes with a footnote.

BE11:04am

The internet's a big place, of which we are but a tiny part.

BE11:04am

What concerns us here each day is money.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Other people's money, mostly.

BE11:05am

But money's not important. Not even a slightly.

BE11:05am

Not when it's weighed against human life.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

That's why, on this side of the page, we're not going to be pointing the lens of finance on an unimaginable humanitarian tragedy. The lens of finance has no right to intrude there.

BE11:05am

If you want to read the latest on Manchester, there's a live blog.

BE11:05am

http://blogs.ft.co...alcon&desktop=true

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Of you want to share your thoughts and theories about Manchester, other websites are available.

BE11:06am

Because today, like every day, we're only going to be talking about money. Which should never, ever be confused with things that are important.

BE11:06am

Let's get on.

11:06 am
undefined
BE11:07am

FTSE flat-ish. Up by 10 points at 7507.

BE11:07am

Very very mixed, no particular trends to pick out.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

As noted on the right, Babcock leading us up.

Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 970.00, up 28.5 (+3.03%), High: 972.00, Low: 943.50, Volume: 1.24m
BE11:08am

Full-years tomorrow, and there are a couple of previews out that would suggest disappointment's unlikely.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley both cautiously positive into the numbers

BE11:10am

Let me grab the former.

BE11:11am

............. Computer's on go-slow. One moment. Getting there.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Okay, finally, Deutsche.

BE11:12am

Babcock's share price has most likely suffered to some extent from the issues in other UK outsourcing names. The valuation, even on cash metrics, is not stretched and so the stock could rebound somewhat further if Babcock was to report a solid FY-17 and supportive growth guidance. We see Babcock as well positioned but we need to see consistency of delivery and proof that cash conversion (esp. to FCF) is on an improving path, in order to be more positive.

BE11:13am

FY-17E results on 24 May: key topics
1/ Organic growth: We do not foresee a material surprise vs. guidance for 4% in H2 (in line with H1). Anything higher would be supportive given the stock’s underperformance and anything lower would lead to de-rating, in our view. We think the market expects guidance of c.6% in FY-18E (in line with Factset consensus). We expect some comment on Magnox and potentially the Type 31s (the UK shipbuilding strategy is due after the UK election).
2/ EBITA margin progression: We forecast -20bps in H2-17E YoY at 11.3% vs. Vuma consensus for a flat margin at 11.5% (guidance slightly lower YoY).
3/ Cash generation: For FY-17 we forecast working capital and provisions outflows reflecting guidance for c.£25m and c.£30m respectively, and capex at 1.5x depreciation as guided by management (1.4x in H1). We are looking for signs that the conversion of net income to levered FCF (incl. JV dividend inflows and additional pension payment outflows) will improve over time.
4/ Balance sheet deployment: Leverage is fairly low (FY-17E 1.8x net debt/EBITDA) and we look forward to any comments on deployment options.
5/ New divisions: Babcock will report under both the old and new divisions will guide under the new structure.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We derive our TP using a 30-year DCF model with 7% WACC (RfR 4%, ERP 4.5%, beta 1x). Babcock trades on a calendarised 2018E P/E of 11x, DB-defined cash P/E of c.15x, DB-defined FCF yield to EV of 6%, DB-defined FCF to equity of 7% and dividend yield of 3%. Upside risks include: large contract wins, growth rebound at MCS, improving cash flow, better profitability than expected, value-add M&A. Downside risks include contract award delays, reduced profitability on public contracts, operational issues, lack of growth opportunities outside of the UK, slower-than-expected cash conversion improvement.

BE11:14am

And the MOST preview seems to have gone out last week so I won't bother sharing that.

undefined
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Homeserve mentioned.

HomeServe PLC (HSV:LSE): Last: 789.50, up 87.5 (+12.46%), High: 803.00, Low: 717.50, Volume: 766.82k
BE11:15am

Big, big rally on what is in truth a rather small beat.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

The positive is that the US business seems to be gaining some traction.

BE11:16am

The negative is that it's Homeserve. Its business is largely built on confusion among people who get the flyer attached to their water bill and end up buying insurance they have little or no chance of actually using.

BE11:18am

That's priced at very little in the first year then cranks stratospherically in the second. Which is something the FCA's looking at, of course.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Though I guess we knew all that yesterday. What we didn't know was the FY numbers, which as I say are fine.

BE11:18am

Here's Caz to summarise.

BE11:19am

HomeServe has delivered 22% growth in adjusted operating profit in FY17, towards the top end of the consensus range and 1% above our estimate. Though boosted by an FX benefit on translation, underlying organic growth was strong, reflecting the increasing traction of HomeServe’s business in North America, as well as solid growth in other markets. We increase our estimate for FY18 operating profit by 1% to £132.4 million.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

HomeServe described FY17 as a 'transformational year' for its business in North America. The acquisition of USP accelerated the growth in operating profit (+50%) and customer numbers, which were up 28%, passing 3 million. Organic growth was also an important factor. HomeServe is now at 50 million affinity partner households, in our opinion well on the path to achieve its target of 80 million in due course.

BE11:20am

France and Spain also mildly positive.

BE11:20am

We have increased our adjusted profit before tax estimate by 1% to £132.4 million in FY18e and set a new DCF-derived target price of 650p

11:20 am
BE11:20am

And Liberum.

BE11:22am

We maintain our estimates for FY 18, having outlined our rationale in detail in our note released in April. We continue to expect PBT of £136m, an increase of 21% on FY 17, and we
continue to expect FD EPS of 31.4p with a usual H2 weighting of c.70%. We assume that net capex falls from £66m in FY 17 to c. £25m in FY 18. We continue to expect that net debt decreases each year to the end of our forecasting horizon assuming no further acquisitions and expect net debt / EBITDA to fall from 1.9x in FY 17 to 0.7x in FY 20. We believe there continues to be plenty of headroom given HomeServe’s strong cash generation, and c .£400m of facilities including a £300m RCF committed to 2019, a €50m term loan for re-payment by 2020, and £50m of private placement funding due for repayment in 2022. We do not expect any impact from the increase in IPT (increasing
from 10% currently to 12% from 1st June) and the company sees it as a straight pass-through to customers.

BE11:22am

We see a CY 17 P/E of 23.4x falling to 20.8x in CY 18 as a relatively high multiple, but TSR will come from growth, yield and occasional specials or earnings enhancing deals. We think it is legitimate to view HomeServe as a scalable platform, capable of exceptional growth. SoTP gives a fair value of 760p. BUY.

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

On the other side of the board we have ..........

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 319.02, down 17.58 (-5.22%), High: 328.80, Low: 316.70, Volume: 1.53m
11:24 am
BE11:24am

UBS has gone to Frankie & Benny's.

BE11:25am

(@Aussie Red: did I put Monday in the headline? Eesh. Sorry. I'm an idiot.)

BE11:25am

And they're not terribly impressed.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

You'd have thought that statement didn't need further explanation, but they've still managed 30 pages.

BE11:26am

The upshot here is that F&B's is still overly expensive.

BE11:26am

(@Stringer: don't do that. Okay?)

11:27 am
BE11:28am

As in, it's still more expensive than a Wetherspoons or whatever, meaning they're going to be sacrificing margin yet not driving significant like-for-likes from the two-burgers-for-a-fiver crowd.

BE11:28am

Here's the summary.

BE11:28am

Core to the turnaround strategy for Frankie & Benny's is a new menu, aimed at improving the value proposition. After its recent menu launch, we have analysed the new F&B proposition along with 20 key competitors, with our analysis indicating that, while prices have fallen (c.6% on average), a value gap remains versus the branded pub chains which are on average 22% cheaper. Given these brands also focus on the family value orientated market, we see risk that the F&B price cuts will not drive the required footfall increase from the core family value orientated customer F&B is looking to attract to offset price reductions. We cut our EPS estimates by -4%/-17% in 2017E/18E, and downgrade to Sell after the strong recent share price performance and our view that the turnaround for F&B looks challenging based on changes implemented so far.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

We have conducted our second pricing analysis on F&B, looking at the impact of the new menu and the pricing differential between F&B and 20 of its largest competitors, comparing a basket of 24 menu items. Key findings include: (1) F&B pricing down c.6% on average vs. competitor pricing up on average 4% since our Sep-16 analysis; (2) Despite the convergence in pricing, a value gap remains with core competitors the branded pub chains, who remain on average 22% cheaper than F&B (vs. 31% in Sep-16 analysis); (3) Menu complexity remains an issue, with F&B having over double the number of main courses versus the peer average.

BE11:29am

While we believe the strategy is moving in the right direction, we see greater risk that, with the F&B value positioning still ahead of core competitors, price cuts will not drive the required footfall increase to offset the LFL pressure from falling prices. As a result, we reduce our LFL growth forecast to 0% in 2018E (previously +2%), with further margin pressure as a result.

BE11:29am

Our DCF-based price target assumes a WACC of 8.5% and LTGR of 1.5%. Restaurant Group is current trading on c.18x 2018E PE which we believe doesn’t reflect the risks associated with the strategy. Our target price implies a 2018E PE of 14.4x.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

BE11:30am

BE11:30am

The hell's a "Fayre & Square"?

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Second thoughts, I probably don't want to know.

BE11:31am

BE11:32am

Also argues that the menus at F&B are too long.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which is the very definition of the paradox of choice, I guess.

BE11:33am

BE11:34am

Dunno about you, but I find menu engineering fascinating. Meant to ask about it at last year's Camp AV when we had Russell Norman and Adam Hyman in to talk about restaurant economics, but I forgot.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:35am

Do we stick to sellside?

BE11:35am

(@Flaneur: +1. Opera's great.)

11:35 am
BE11:36am

(Not investment advice.)

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 93.25, down 4.5 (-4.60%), High: 96.50, Low: 92.25, Volume: 1.36m
BE11:36am

Gone sub 1p in old money.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Citi's gone to sell ahead of the rights issue, which feels increasingly inevitable.

BE11:38am

And the inevitability of it creates the death spiral. It's sad to watch, in a way, though management could've solved all this by raising a decent amount in 2015.

BE11:38am

Citi's note is bracingly straightforward.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

As we did in January 2012 and March 2015 (see Steering the Ship through Stormy Waters and Tiring Balance Sheets), we are again cautioning investors that there is a high likelihood that LON will have to approach shareholders for further capital in the next 6-12 months, especially if current PGM prices prevail.
We estimate that LON’s tangible net worth could fall below the $1.1bn level when it reports its FY17 results to September 2017. This level is significant since it would trigger LON’s debt covenants.
We think this could result in LON’s fourth rights issue in eight years.
We are unsure about investor appetite to support another rights issue, given the last one was less than two years ago.
This could call into question the future shape of LON’s business.
We revise our estimates, marking to market 1H17, which leads us to cut our TP 20% to GBP0.95 (ZAR15.42). We downgrade the stock to Sell/High Risk.
We argue that, as the industry’s highest-cost player and with limited strategic flexibility, LON remains structurally challenged and a speculative play on PGM prices.

BE11:41am

(@Lefevre: sympathies. My experience of Wagamama is that it's the UK's most successful application of assembly-line catering. Highly recommend getting a seat next to the kitchen and watch the order throughput during a Saturday lunch shift. It's very impressive.)

BE11:42am

(Also, if you take away any tip from today's session, take this one. Wagamama in Gatwick does breakfast. It's good, it's civilised, it's never more than two-thirds full and it's a bargain.)

11:42 am
undefined
BE11:43am

On we go then.

BE11:43am

Greencore, I think, was mentioned.

11:43 am
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 733.50, down 5 (-0.68%), High: 740.50, Low: 733.50, Volume: 167.91k
BE11:45am

(@Vixal: Second Shot on Bethnal Green Rd.)

BE11:46am

It's another case of the shares falling quite hard into results for reasons entirely unrelated to those results.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

You'll remember the concerns about Peacock Foods after its main customer, Tyson, bought Advancepiere, one of Peacock's main rivals.

BE11:47am

Today's numbers tell us literally nothing about whether the US business should now be valued rather less than it was.

BE11:48am

However, the figures are decent. Here's SocGen.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Actually, not SocGen. It's a pain to cut and paste. Here's Kepler.

BE11:49am

The headline H1 2017 numbers for LFL performance and the EBITA were in line with our expectations. The large Peacock deal seems on track, which provides some relief. Management confirmed the FY outlook for a profit in line with market consensus. We do not expect to see significant changes to FY 2017 consensus numbers.

BE11:49am

The H1 EBITA of GBP55m matched our GBP55m forecast and also the split between the UK and US provided no surprises. This implied an 80bp margin decline YOY, as new contracts lift sales growth but weigh on margins in 2017. As expected, LFL sales growth was very strong at 10.6% in the UK (forecast: +10.5%) and 6% in the US legacy business (8.5% forecast) based on market growth and business wins.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

On US performance, the progress at Peacock was most important, and this acquired operation grew sales by 7% on a LFL basis and delivered EBITA as expected. The salads and meal kits grew particularly well. The integration is progressing well, according to management.

BE11:50am

The company believes that it can meet market expectations for FY 2017, which is more or less in line with our forecast of GBP144m in EBITA. New contracts will continue to support LFL growth in H2 2017, but start-up costs will be lower than in H1 2017. There is some cost inflation on raw materials and labour, but these are expected to be offset.

undefined
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Should probably mention Brown-Forman ......

BE11:51am

Post its big spike yesterday.

BE11:52am

Even though we've nothing much to say about it right now.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Suffice to say it was probably not interest triggered by the 0.2% improvement in April NABCA volumes.

BE11:53am

And of course the idea of liquor maker consolidation comes around fairly regularly, and involves the same names every time.

BE11:55am

Here's the market share chart, via Exane.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

BE11:56am

That was put together in a note bashing around the idea of Diageo being a target for 3G etc.

BE11:57am

But in what is a reasonably fragmented marketplace, is there logic to Diageo or whoever doing something defensive before 3G gets back into mega-buy mode?

11:58 am
BE11:58am

I've no idea. But it's a thought, right? A thought I'm vocalising here.

undefined
BE11:59am

Haven't mentioned Imagination, but the ROTR has.

11:59 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 108.07, up 6.82 (+6.74%), High: 109.00, Low: 104.50, Volume: 2.44m
BE11:59am

Tsinghua Unigroup goes over 3%.

BE12:00pm

Is that a prelude to a bid? Liberum's hopeful.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We believe Tsinghua is a potential buyer of the whole company, given the value of Imagination's intellectual property to building up China's domestic semiconductor industry. China-based Spreadtrum which is owned by Tsinghua is also a licensee of Imagination's PowerVR. Imagination has publicly stated that it does not intend to sell the whole company, but only the MIPS and Ensigma businesses. It plans to retain PowerVR. We believe this is a sub-optimal solution as reflected in our Hold recommendation. However, there is still a possibility of the whole company being acquired, which could result in valuations well above the current level.

BE12:01pm

I'd note in passing that Intel and Apple have both held stakes in Imagination without buying it.

BE12:02pm

(Though Apple did talk about it once.)

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

So .... Could be a defensive move for a key partner in trouble .......... Much like Intel's investment was.

BE12:03pm

(@DutchBrat: yep.)

undefined
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Okay, we're done.

BE12:04pm

Thanks ROTR for making my life easier.

BE12:05pm

We'll see you back here tomorrow.

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:29am

Want it in charts?
